abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, but the project's overall sustainability
            is rated "unlikely." This is because maintaining
            the condition of the Harad-Huth Road over the long-term will
            depend primarily upon regular and adequate routine and
            periodic maintenance, as well as upon the security situation
            in the area. Both World Bank and Borrower performances are
            assessed as overall satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project included the following: Conflicts among tribes and
            between tribes and the Government caused significant delays
            in project implementation. For those projects that may raise
            objections or are likely to incite opposition in tribal
            areas, more emphasis should be placed on minimizing the
            political ramifications during project design, and
            beneficiaries should be consulted during preparation. the
            use of force account to build roads and other transport
            infrastructure should be carefully considered, and only used
            under exceptional circumstnaces. Due to a lack of
            understanding of Bank procurement procedures and the need to
            follow them closely, the acquisition of works, goods, and
            services suffered during the early stages of the project. To
            avoid such problems, there should be at least one dedicated
            counterpart professional with in-depth knowledge and
            practical experience of Bank procurement procedures. The
            lack of adequate financial records also was a shortcoming of
            the project.
